stem: An 18-month-old child is brought to the ED by a frantic parent. Based on the documentation in the Pediatric Toxicology & Observation Log, what is the nurse's highest priority action?

options.text: Administer IV naloxone and prepare for repeated doses.
Administer syrup of Ipecac to induce vomiting.
Prepare for discharge once the child is awake and alert.

rationale.correct: The child is experiencing life-threatening opioid toxicity (methadone). IV naloxone is the highest priority to restore respiratory drive. Because methadone is a long-acting opioid (half-life 24-36 hours), a single dose of naloxone (short-acting) will wear off, and the child will likely experience respiratory depression again. Repeated doses or a continuous naloxone infusion will likely be necessary for the next 24-48 hours.
clinicalPearls: Methadone: One pill can kill a child.
Pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression indicate opioid toxicity until proven otherwise.
Ipecac is not recommended as it increases the risk of aspiration.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing gastric lavage as the priority.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize airway and breathing. Address respiratory depression with an antidote first. Lavage is secondary and carries a high risk in a somnolent patient.

mnemonic.title: Tiny Toxic
mnemonic.expansion: One pill. Long chill (methadone duration). Give the Narcan until they're drill (alert).

exhibits.title: SBAR Situation
exhibits.content:
Situation: Accidental ingestion of grandparent's medication.
Background: Parent found child playing with an open bottle of methadone 10mg tablets 1 hour ago. Bottle was previously full.
Assessment: Child is very difficult to arouse. Pupils are 1mm (pinpoint). Respiratory rate is 8 and shallow.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs Trends
exhibits.content:
Indicator Arrival (10 mins ago) Current
Heart Rate 110 84 (Bradycardia starting)
Resp Rate 14 8 (Dropping)
SpO2 94% 88% (on room air)

exhibits.title: Methadone Reference
exhibits.content:
Drug Type: Long-acting synthetic opioid.
Half-life: 24-36 hours.
Pediatric Danger: 1 pill can be lethal to a toddler.
